thread_text:
603219684402601984 [2015-05-26] @loopholekid 💜 2 🔁 1 [(SEED) type=semantic_search]
If you grow up and still want to be a child, you might have done something wrong.

===

1206274851545026560 [2019-12-15] @QiaochuYuan 💜 67 🔁 6
one way to reframe the childhood trauma stuff i keep talking about is that people adapt to the environment parents + school create growing up and then are thrust into a completely different environment they're no longer adapted to upon adulthood
↓
1206274875112841217 [2019-12-15] @QiaochuYuan 💜 44 🔁 4 [(SEED) type=semantic_search]
in some sense parents + school can end up making and then breaking a promise: if you just keep obeying us, keep your head down and do what you're s'posed to, everything will be fine. that wouldn't be so bad if it were *true*!
↓
1206274882251575296 [2019-12-15] @QiaochuYuan 💜 37 🔁 1
you get a visceral sense of how much of this conditioning people still have if you teach a class or run a workshop for adults. you can tell those fuckers to do all sorts of crap and they'll mostly just do it! you're standing up in front of a room, that means you're the teacher!
↓
1206274888979214336 [2019-12-15] @QiaochuYuan 💜 27
doubly true if you have them do something where blindly following instructions is not a guarantee of good results, eg improv. you can learn to spot the "good students" who are trying to get "good grades" on the task, and i'm calling myself out here

===

1285353971054452741 [2020-07-20] @natural_hazard 💜 30 🔁 2 [(SEED) type=semantic_search]
"But I think there’s something ominous about a kid so eager-to-please that he sits perfectly still for fifteen minutes waiting for a marshmallow."
↓
1285368351255072769 [2020-07-21] @natural_hazard 💜 7
lol :)
i tried this sort of stats dump
existential crisis left me feeling valueless, so i aimed at gaining "general strength"

worked for a bit, but eventually realized that "arbitrary motivational abilities" aren't real. https://t.co/uev7clOCc0

===

1455957919770497025 [2021-11-03] @m_ashcroft 💜 99 🔁 4
Every so often I think back to the ridiculous grading system I had at school.

A - E meant performance

1 - 5 meant effort

Of course getting an A1 was considered better than an A5. "He's doing well, but he's not TRYING!"

Well, good! What good would looking like I'm trying do?
↓
1455958356934467588 [2021-11-03] @m_ashcroft 💜 46 🔁 3
"you must try to think, you must try to pay attention!"

no, actually, these things happen in spite of any trying, not because of it

trying interferes, in fact, because the part of me that tries isn't the part of me that actually thinks or pays attention

nonsense, all of it
↓
1455958834111995908 [2021-11-03] @m_ashcroft 💜 27
this is one of the most important things in life to unlearn of course

but if the illusion is too strong you have no other way to get rid of it than to try not to try

and then you are lost, until one day you see that cessation of trying is quite different from trying not to try
↓
1455960073210105866 [2021-11-03] @m_ashcroft 💜 24
it's the *cessation of trying* that I teach

and it's funny to reflect on how easy it is to forget that simple move of "stop trying"

I got trapped, my fellow AT trainees got stuck, etc

it takes time to realise that all the tricks you thought it was are just different tryings
↓
1455960917485801489 [2021-11-03] @m_ashcroft 💜 29
and if I sound like Alan Watts then that should come as no surprise

it's all the same illusion, pointed out over and over in different words, in different times

I hope that more people become able to see through it, our future depends on it
↓
1455961512330285062 [2021-11-03] @m_ashcroft 💜 15
c.f. connection with brain lateralisation as Iain McGilchrist talks about it - the left hemisphere is like a hall of mirrors @Malcolm_Ocean @Jeanvaljean689
↓
1455961711282950145 [2021-11-03] @m_ashcroft 💜 15 [(SEED) type=quote_of_root]
worthy inclusion in this thread, captures the bind perfectly

just imagine you were that child and you forgot you were doing this, it just became automatic

https://t.co/j3yqH9wL8L
  [Quoting @RomeoStevens76: "If you manage to control yourself there will be ice cream" said the parent.  "I sure hope this doesn't have unforeseen lifelong consequences" thought the child, doing their best to physically tense the body in the higher ice cream probability shape.]

===

1479317787747123200 [2022-01-07] @QiaochuYuan 💜 88 🔁 4
it's not exactly as if undoing social conditioning is a pure good. it's more that obeying social conditioning is your end of keeping up the social contract, and insofar as the social contract sucks, undoing social conditioning is a prerequisite to renegotiating it
↓
1479318450082246657 [2022-01-07] @QiaochuYuan 💜 16 🔁 1 [(SEED) type=quote_of_semantic_search]
especially relevant if your social conditioning comes from an environment you're not in anymore

https://t.co/AW05WS0lxf
  [Quoting @QiaochuYuan: in some sense parents + school can end up making and then breaking a promise: if you just keep obeying us, keep your head down and do what you're s'posed to, everything will be fine. that wouldn't be so bad if it were *true*!]

===

1502783983729446912 [2022-03-12] @IaimforGOAT 
When I was a kid, for a short while I got attracted into poetry, my poems were not good but they were very fun to write
↓
1502783986430623745 [2022-03-12] @IaimforGOAT 
So I wrote a few and then some more. It was fun, so I kept playing with the words like a puzzle. 

Learning by doing and not caring how you call that technique or wtv
↓
1502783988875907073 [2022-03-12] @IaimforGOAT 
After a few days of doing this I noticed that something was **different**, a very small difference but it was there. I couldn't pinpoint what it was tho, so I kinda ignored it.
↓
1502783991811878915 [2022-03-12] @IaimforGOAT 
Some time after that I realized the structure of my thoughts was mutating... EVERY. SINGLE. THOUGHT. Now came in the structure of a poem.
↓
1502783994408144902 [2022-03-12] @IaimforGOAT 
I got scared af. I thought I broke my brain. The (bad) poems were flowing as naturally as any other thought before. 

So... As soon as I noticed it I immediately stopped writing poems!
↓
1502783997004374018 [2022-03-12] @IaimforGOAT 
Looking back at it... It's a bit sad. I was having a lot of fun and it probably would not have any negative impact at all...

Maybe this was even one of the first instances I experienced the flow state ─ this may be even before I started gaming, not sure tho.
↓
1502783999814602753 [2022-03-12] @IaimforGOAT  [(SEED) type=semantic_search]
I wish I could go back and talk with that kid. Don't be scared kid, it is just good as is! Enjoy it. This good thing will not be balanced by a bad thing later.
↓
1502784002788364297 [2022-03-12] @IaimforGOAT 
This good thing will not be balanced by a bad thing later.

This good thing will not be balanced by a bad thing later.

This good thing will not be balanced by a bad thing later.
↓
1502784006013825026 [2022-03-12] @IaimforGOAT 
This is a pattern, this kid didn't knew he would come back to. But he did, and so do I.
↓
1502784008563961857 [2022-03-12] @IaimforGOAT 
When something very good happens that manages to capture my whole self into it, my attention is 110% on it, I put one of my feet a little bit back. As if at some point I will have to sprint out of it...
↓
1502784011327918086 [2022-03-12] @IaimforGOAT 
In my experience, I have never have had to sprint out of it. Never. So why do I have this instinct?
↓
1502784013685121028 [2022-03-12] @IaimforGOAT 
I feel like this is something I need to figure out, because if I want to do great things it will come out of times where something captures me so hard I forget to eat and sleep. I almost forget to breathe.
↓
1502784016205893640 [2022-03-12] @IaimforGOAT 
Compounding on this is how you end up doing great things, and to be able to compound I need to figure this out.
↓
1502784018999398400 [2022-03-12] @IaimforGOAT 
There's a dot to connect here.

===

1524408561144668161 [2022-05-11] @TylerAlterman 💜 438 🔁 29 💬 1
mfs confused about why we adults have problems w consent when everyone spent their first ~18 yrs in training to accept that our consent doesn’t matter
↓
1524410668660801536 [2022-05-11] @TylerAlterman 💜 181 🔁 7
mfs confused about why we adults have problems identifying what we want…when everyone spent their first ~18yrs being taught that what we want might be overridden by authority figures who Know Better at any time
↓
1524411385987448832 [2022-05-11] @TylerAlterman 💜 47 [(SEED) type=semantic_search]
(Granted, a lot of things we want as kids are literally impossible or might severely injure us. Writing this here before someone comments with this banal bs 😘)
↓
1524687209533648897 [2022-05-12] @puheenix 
@TylerAlterman yep, and discerning needs/wants/possibilities is the path to adulthood. so we block that path by forbidding desire itself & then wonder why modern adults are anything but

1574342815429304320 [2022-09-26] @visakanv 💜 106 🔁 8 [(SEED) type=semantic_search]
sometimes i feel like a child who's been given free rein to eat whatever he likes at an ice cream shop and i'm crying because there's too much ice cream
↓
1754199988660502604 [2024-02-04] @visakanv 💜 20 🔁 3
i was trying really hard to find this comic a while ago, and now that i've found it, i've lost the thread that i wanted to put it in, lol. but i'll find it here next time https://t.co/3V9Z0DudSp

===

1574596837721669632 [2022-09-27] @m_ashcroft 💜 75 🔁 2
Once again thinking back to when I noticed some part of me that was convinced it needed to 'do' the world, as if it had taken on responsibility and burden for the ongoing existence of everything

And it was using muscle tension to do it

When it let go everything got more vivid
↓
1574597467395747840 [2022-09-27] @m_ashcroft 💜 16
I suspect this pattern is probably quite common, just going on below conscious awareness

probably an example of inappropriate learning of cause and effect in childhood

"I wanted to X happen, and when I happened to be doing Y, X happened, so Y must cause X. I must always Y."
↓
1574597642864435200 [2022-09-27] @m_ashcroft 💜 23 🔁 1 [(SEED) type=quote_of_root]
I will again QT one of the finest tweets on the bird site

https://t.co/zH2ZT1pa32
  [Quoting @RomeoStevens76: "If you manage to control yourself there will be ice cream" said the parent.  "I sure hope this doesn't have unforeseen lifelong consequences" thought the child, doing their best to physically tense the body in the higher ice cream probability shape.]
↓
1574597996742062080 [2022-09-27] @m_ashcroft 💜 21
this is one of the things that Alexander Technique gets you to notice and let go of

you start to notice "huh I sure do something weird for some reason under certain circumstances, that's interesting... what if I were to explore how I might not do that in those circumstances"
↓
1574598387458281474 [2022-09-27] @m_ashcroft 💜 20
I've never encountered any version of this where you can force not doing the thing

it's more like, if the thing is something that is ready to be not done, then not doing it becomes available

this is not the same as "in fact it is not safe to not X, but I shall not X anyway"

===

1585624132984897538 [2022-10-27] @m_ashcroft 💜 63 🔁 1 [(SEED) type=quote_of_root]
I just shared this in a group chat so it feels right to retweet what might be my favourite ever tweet again https://t.co/2TJogIvjrw
  [Quoting @RomeoStevens76: "If you manage to control yourself there will be ice cream" said the parent.  "I sure hope this doesn't have unforeseen lifelong consequences" thought the child, doing their best to physically tense the body in the higher ice cream probability shape.]

===

1610358856273592324 [2023-01-03] @RichDecibels 💜 104 🔁 5
wowwwww big discovery: spontaneous TRE muscle trembling plus MDMA is hecking big deal for somatic healing without a therapist

===

1610360579998482434 [2023-01-03] @RichDecibels 💜 47 🔁 1
club wisdom tells you how to deal with muscle tension on ecstacy= chew gum, suck on a dummy, take magnesium

WRONG ANSWER (for me)

the muscle tension IS THE MEDICINE. listen to what the muscle wants, if it wants to twitch let it, just let the animal parts of you take over
↓
1610360947071385600 [2023-01-03] @RichDecibels 💜 52
hypothesis: mdma induces felt sense of safety in your animal body so you have an opportunity to STOP RESISTING the muscle tension that you have been carrying around all these months and years

inhibitions drop, shakes take over, tension oscillates back and forth till its done
↓
1610363358712107008 [2023-01-03] @RichDecibels 💜 35
and maybe you tender nerds love magnesium so much because it gives you some relief from the pent up feelings you have stuck in your muscles eh
↓
1610370762975903746 [2023-01-03] @RichDecibels 💜 22 🔁 2
👀👀👀👀 here is a necessary warning

https://t.co/4rKO6u83au
  [Quoting @hormeze: @RichDecibels in case u havent been warned, plz be careful with TRE, and with recommending it to people with trauma, IMO it is employed very irresponsibly, ive seen the main guy (david) hurt people very badly with this technique, and i myself was hurt by it as well]
↓
1610373873706627072 [2023-01-03] @RichDecibels 💜 14
https://t.co/5TanlJM1aM
  [Quoting @RichDecibels: @bastard_brian I noticed muscles trembling, welcomed them, then I imagined Peter Levine asking me to "complete the movement", what does my body want to do? answer, push hard against a very heavy thing  did that then: "what does this remind you of?"  then, flood of intense memories]
↓
1610374299243745283 [2023-01-03] @RichDecibels 💜 14
PS I'm doing this with my most trusted friend in the world, FFS don't try to deal with trauma on your own people!!
↓
1610375137890639872 [2023-01-03] @RichDecibels 💜 28 🔁 2
I was a wriggly kid, always wanted to move in peculiar ways, tapping fingers, making noise, bouncing my heels under the school desk

all that movement was a brilliant mammal strategy for dealing with stress and all of it was physically punished out of me when I was a little boy
↓
1610376578600693761 [2023-01-03] @RichDecibels 💜 21 🔁 1
very grateful I met @awarenesss this year, he is a grown up, who moves thru a room just like my little boy self wanted to move. he reads group vibe and changes posture to serve it. eg this is getting tense, I will make sure you don't sweep it under the rug. or, OK, PLAY TIME
↓
1610411115195809793 [2023-01-03] @RichDecibels 💜 10
shit I wondering how this intersects with stammering!? phenomenologically correlated at least

any reacts @aprivatething
↓
1610634815430066176 [2023-01-04] @RichDecibels 💜 12
@embryosophy do you have any reaction to my hunch that long term locked up muscle tension is the result of actively resisting the body's need to tremble. so the way to release is to find the conditions where you can stop resisting
↓
1610720789535547392 [2023-01-04] @SarahAMcManus 💜 9 [(SEED) type=quote_of_root]
@RichDecibels @embryosophy https://t.co/jE2kxoHqO1
  [Quoting @RomeoStevens76: "If you manage to control yourself there will be ice cream" said the parent.  "I sure hope this doesn't have unforeseen lifelong consequences" thought the child, doing their best to physically tense the body in the higher ice cream probability shape.]

1787687636242669988 [2024-05-07] @tr_babb 💜 39 🔁 4 💬 1
the body abounds with software errors

I had an upper respiratory virus this past winter (covid negative), and my throat got very sore

since healing, discomfort (not pain) with swallowing has lingered. my throat felt like it wasn't fully clearing saliva
↓
1787687637727564081 [2024-05-07] @tr_babb 💜 11 🔁 1
this feeling came and went, but finally yesterday I decided to direct serious body-attention to figuring out what was going on. was worried maybe there was scar tissue on my epiglottis, or worse, neuron damage
↓
1787687639237489103 [2024-05-07] @tr_babb 💜 11 🔁 2
after some minutes of experimenting, I think I figured it out: the sore throat had trained my tongue to swallow without touching it there, lest it spike with pain. it'd retained this habit past the original problem
↓
1787687640629961154 [2024-05-07] @tr_babb 💜 17 🔁 2
I noticed this when I tried forcing my tongue in different positions while swallowing, and discovered a subtle "flinch" sensation, expecting pain to come when pushing on the back of my throat; and "surprise" when none came
↓
1787687642072821976 [2024-05-07] @tr_babb 💜 17 🔁 1
I'd unconsciously adapted to lose an important "wiping" gesture that was clearing away saliva. when I deliberately put it back, it felt better

I've been deliberately practicing the normal motion all day and I think it's working. repetition should extinguish the pain-expectation
↓
1787687643523981737 [2024-05-07] @tr_babb 💜 26 🔁 2 [(SEED) type=quote_of_root]
I think this kind of stuff is common in the human condition. the direct emotional equivalent to this is  trauma; aka carrying an adaptive behavior into a situation where it is no longer helpful

(that pattern is the source of a huge amt of human suffering)
https://t.co/zZ6XSRYAiS
  [Quoting @RomeoStevens76: "If you manage to control yourself there will be ice cream" said the parent.  "I sure hope this doesn't have unforeseen lifelong consequences" thought the child, doing their best to physically tense the body in the higher ice cream probability shape.]
↓
1787687645851889761 [2024-05-07] @tr_babb 💜 12 🔁 1
I've seen this in myself in other cases too. an arm muscle problem fixed by very slightly adjusting how I held my hands on my keyboard. adjusting my running gait months after an ankle injury months after it had healed

ostensible hardware problems that were all entirely software
↓
1787687647307354175 [2024-05-07] @tr_babb 💜 6
I wonder if this is just me, but I see hints of the same shape of problem sometimes in other people— a coworker who held his weight strangely on his left foot; his entire shoe crushed and contorted under his heel. years of that would certainly do Bad Things to joints, tendons
↓
1787687648620097652 [2024-05-07] @tr_babb 💜 9
someone else who was battling neck problems; had micro-adjusted every aspect of their work setup; was on painkillers, etc etc

"what's your sleeping position?"

"..."
"hmm, yeah, it is kind of contorted"

problems went away shortly after that discussion
↓
1787687650188734483 [2024-05-07] @tr_babb 💜 8
I've said this in another thread, but I think unusual shoes (i.e. barefoot / toe shoes) do their work by forcing people to totally reinvent bad gaits that are probably enabled by cushy modern shoes. if your gait is ~okay, these will probably do ~nothing for you
↓
1787687651610624472 [2024-05-07] @tr_babb 💜 14 🔁 2
I wonder what fraction of chronic, bizarre, idiopathic health problems are things that could potentially be solved by very careful observation and introspection. sadly these moves are hard to teach
↓
1787687653066105148 [2024-05-07] @tr_babb 💜 9
I'm still somewhat unsure of whether to characterize my current experience as tiny-brain body awareness or giant-brain. it's quite possible I'm only able to make these simple fixes because I'm dumb enough to have them in the first place

1787687654454444451 [2024-05-07] @tr_babb 💜 5

1802789213886365759 [2024-06-17] @johnsonmxe 💜 259 🔁 19
Quick model of jhanaThe vasomuscular system (“tension”) acts to collapse uncertainty, set context & stabilize local neural patterns. Actions of this system typically feel bad. But you can also use it as a wave machine to feel good. Each jhana is a different wave machine setting
↓
1802789308304445919 [2024-06-17] @johnsonmxe 💜 34 🔁 1
I wrote about the computational role of the vasomuscular system last year. Basically, vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) shake nearby neurons when they get stuck in ambivalence, and clench to freeze nearby neural patternshttps://t.co/vzGxzCVukw
↓
1802789372326236460 [2024-06-17] @johnsonmxe 💜 30 🔁 1
Usually this muscle contraction logic is highly local. VSMCs essentially act as busybody micromanagers of nearby neurons: a little more blood *here* & a little more tension *there*, and prediction error goes down…https://t.co/205pbA3nRw
↓
1802789577364828411 [2024-06-17] @johnsonmxe 💜 30 [(SEED) type=quote_of_root]
A great example of this system is how muscles focus our eyes by micro-adjustments in tension — probably something similar happens in lots of tissues. The primary task of VSMCs is to contract, release, & clench in a way that minimizes prediction errorhttps://t.co/XCb1s2Jr5T
  [Quoting @RomeoStevens76: "If you manage to control yourself there will be ice cream" said the parent.  "I sure hope this doesn't have unforeseen lifelong consequences" thought the child, doing their best to physically tense the body in the higher ice cream probability shape.]
↓
1802789735192240568 [2024-06-17] @johnsonmxe 💜 32
We have two ways of minimizing prediction error: passive inference (build good models of the world) and active inference (create predictions, then make them true). I believe the latter is managed by VSMCs: tension is prediction, prediction is tensionhttps://t.co/OXkqzVRUfg
  [Quoting @johnsonmxe: @metaLulie @moissanist Essentially, the muscular system (in particular smooth muscles & fascia, and in particular VSMCs) holds tension as a way to restrict the patterns of the neural system. Sort of like how pinching a vibrating system reduces the ways it can vibrate. These pinches can be brief, or can…]
↓
1802789805992059140 [2024-06-17] @johnsonmxe 💜 42 🔁 5
Human imagination (and thus tension) is roughly the most powerful force in the universe: if we imagine something, we slowly reorganize our bodies, families, & civilizations to expect and conjure it — whether it’s good or bad
↓
1802789867203838066 [2024-06-17] @johnsonmxe 💜 31
Jhanas repurpose this system by pointing it at predicting (creating) internal harmony. “There is a warm and pleasant feeling here.” Now your VSMCs’ job is to make that true. The most effective way to instantiate this is coordinated waves traveling through the body’s muscles
↓
1802790088797299172 [2024-06-17] @johnsonmxe 💜 29
I.e. jhanas turn the body’s muscles into a wave machine that rhythmically agitates nearby neurons. We’re not in the habit of using our muscles like this because most settings produce destructive interference — feels bad. But some produce constructive interferencehttps://t.co/qBNazJ6xMW
↓
1802790161975288104 [2024-06-17] @johnsonmxe 💜 22
It can be slow to find the right rhythms for constructive interference — most regions have a dominant frequency but bodies have many regions. But harmony anywhere makes harmony easier everywhere else: once we dial it in somewhere, the muscular waves can slowly spread
↓
1802790264437969134 [2024-06-17] @johnsonmxe 💜 22
Jhana 1 would be the most frothy harmony. Once it becomes strong and recruits most of the body, the most effective way to further reduce the prediction error for bodily pleasure is to turn down the froth — to reduce the power of rhythmic agitation
↓
1802790329449681077 [2024-06-17] @johnsonmxe 💜 23
Putting you into jhana 2, a less frothy state. This repeats with each step, until the neural system can find its own subtle resonances by itself — the “formless jhanas”. The wave machine is just a whisper at this point, ripples on a glassy lake
↓
1802790406083531138 [2024-06-17] @johnsonmxe 💜 22
The lower jhanas have to happen first because your vasomuscular system is busy trying to reduce local prediction error. As you point it inwards & recruit it into helping create global waves, it helps then ‘gets out of the way’. The pleasure becomes more refined
↓
1802790498840842251 [2024-06-17] @johnsonmxe 💜 22
I.e. you can’t jump into upper jhanas directly because your attention is external, vasomuscular system is busy, and neural system is noisy. Solution: point your busybody vasomuscular system inwards by predicting a certain sort of pleasure; as it succeeds it attenuates itselfhttps://t.co/e5RzoqPUnz
↓
1802790586946363662 [2024-06-17] @johnsonmxe 💜 21
I’ve written before that each jhana is like a new phase of matter — and such phase shifts will change system resonant frequencies. But with the vasomuscular system quiet and everything so close to criticality, the system can immediately snap to the new rhythmhttps://t.co/jdik8ncD9Ghttps://t.co/xwcnuXnY7i

1825215573758030003 [2024-08-18] @danallison 💜 1
Inner animal child popped up for me a few days ago after I posted this tweet. I posted it half jokingly, but I’m actually taking the intention pretty seriously as a long term commitment to becoming this kind of person. However, inner animal child was not happy about this plan. https://t.co/s1Poeyph71
  [Quoting @danallison: Starting today, I am a calm focused guy. https://t.co/7X2tbdeXQ8]

1825215580015824978 [2024-08-18] @danallison 💜 3

↓
1825215585342677165 [2024-08-18] @danallison 💜 1
Seems like an impasse. Inner responsible adult wants me to become “calm focused guy”, inner animal child refuses to cooperate. What do?
↓
1825215587272032753 [2024-08-18] @danallison 💜 2
There’s a temptation to frame this situation as a Problem To Solve. But if that’s how we frame it, then we’ve already lost. Inner animal child knows exactly who we’re talking about when we say “problem”.
↓
1825215589398516054 [2024-08-18] @danallison 💜 3
So if it’s not a problem, what is it? One answer that feels resonant right now is play. We’re playing. We’re always playing. Life is play. There are no Problems, only Games.
↓
1825215591520887193 [2024-08-18] @danallison 💜 2
So what’s the game we’re playing? That’s up to us. We get to be creative and see what’s fun and what’s not. One game idea I’ll call CF guy. If animal child doesn’t want to be Calm Focused guy today, then maybe Curious Friendly guy or Compassionate Funny guy or Creative Fast guy.
↓
1825215593555153281 [2024-08-18] @danallison 💜 1

1929001827175117246 [2025-06-01] @the_wilderless 💜 752 🔁 27
just went and got coffee and there were a couple young kids (~2 & ~5ish?) there w their parents; a song came on they liked and they immediately leapt up and started dancing,

and my first impression was the whole 'kids are so free and uninhibited, they just get up and dance' thing,,

and then i noticed how that thought felt automatic-habitual, and not from presence, so I dropped into Presence,

and actually Saw the kids dancing and realized that train of thought is bullshit in a lot of ways I haven't seen people talk about before? 

Like, kids aren't these free-flowing uninhibited streams of energy before society taught them how to behave,

their movements were jerky, stiff, they were clearly locked up in a lot of their torso and limbs, their attention laser-focused on how their parents were responding and re-adjusting their movements around that,

they were just as anxious and locked-up as a lot of adults, just in a very different orientation, an orientation aimed entirely at trying to pull approval from their parents, rather than to avoid disapproval from strangers
↓

rating.reasoning_summary: This strand traces the multi-year evolution of a psychological/somatic concept anchored by RomeoStevens76's 'Ice Cream Probability Shape' tweet (2021). The boundary object is the metaphor of childhood conditioning creating lifelong muscle tension patterns. The discourse is primarily constructive—practitioners of Alexander Technique, somatic therapies, and contemplative practice use the tweet as a shared reference point to explore how early conditioning manifests as physical tension, and how to release it. The arc moves from initial recognition (Qiaochu's 2019 pre-context on school conditioning) through Romeo's crystallization, into practical applications (Rich's TRE/MDMA experiments, Yatharth's 'Walmart problem'), and finally theoretical synthesis (Johnsonmxe's vasomuscular computation model). The strand demonstrates high evolution—from abstract critique to embodied practice to mechanistic theory—and high utility for both the contemplative community and outsiders seeking to understand psychosomatic patterns.

essential_tweets.annotation: Pre-context: Qiaochu identifying the core problem—school/parents create conditioning that doesn't serve adult life
The Artifact: Romeo's Ice Cream tweet—the boundary object that crystallizes the concept of tension-as-strategy
Early interpretation: M_ashcroft connecting to 'trying not to try' and Alexander Technique's cessation of effort
Expansion into consent: Tyler linking childhood conditioning to adult problems with agency and desire
Somatic application: M_ashcroft on muscle tension as inappropriate cause-effect learning, introducing AT as solution
Experimental breakthrough: Rich's discovery of TRE+MDMA for releasing stored tension without therapist
The Walmart Problem: Yatharth's viral thread on judging people who lack 'fixing tension'—showing cultural spread
Case study: Tr_babb's throat tension as software error—concrete example of the pattern in daily life
Theoretical synthesis: Johnsonmxe's vasomuscular computation model explaining the mechanism behind tension-as-prediction
Present-day application: The_wilderless noticing the pattern in dancing children—showing concept's ongoing utility
